reviewText:
There's something wrong with Esther!

In the great tradition of movies from THE BAD SEED to THE RING, ORPHAN gives us a terrifyingly dangerous child named Esther...an orphan from Russia adopted by a loving American family...who soon have deep cause to regret their decision.

It's an old, old cinematic story.  A child who is incredibly intelligent and somehow twisted into a cold-blooded killer.  A brilliant manipulator of adults.  A feared peer.  And for the audience, sometimes a source of discomfort.

It is the level of discomfort that such a film child creates that mostly determines whether this sort of movie works or not.  And I will say, Esther is one of the better child prodigy serial killers I've seen in awhile.  Creepy doesn't quite begin to describe it.

Isabelle Fuhrmann plays this little Russian 9-year-old with an efficiency of movement and a coldness of purpose that is chilling.  When she is first spotted at the Catholic Orphanage by her prospective parents (Vera Farmiga and Peter Sarsgaard), she appears to be a shy but very intelligent girl with a charming Russian accent.  But almost immediately upon her arrival at home, she begins to manipulate the family and remove those who stand in her way...for reasons we don't learn until near the end of the film.

Turns out, this seemingly happy family has a few unhappy moments.  Farmiga is a recovering alcoholic, who still feels the urge.  She's wracked with guilt for nearly costing the life of her young daughter Max, an adorable (and crucially, deaf) young girl...because of her drunken inattentiveness.  Sarsgaard has a lapse of faithfulness in his past.  And the whole family mourns the death of sister Jessica, who died in the womb and whose lost has deeply scarred Farmiga.  Only the older brother seems "normal" and of course he spots the weirdness in Esther right away.

The psychology of the family is critical to Esther's schemes...but they are fairly incidental in a film of this kind.  It's the creepiness and preternatural "talents" of the young girl in manipulating, hurting and dispatching her rivals that draws us in.  There are no moments of supernatural occurrences in the film...but it plays like an old-school horror film.  For its two hour running time, you'll be well entertained.

Having "classy" actors like Farmiga and Sarsgaard on  hand gives ORPHAN a sheen of respectability, as does the always welcome presence of CCH Pounder as the head of the orphanage.  But as is so often the case, any post-viewing scrutiny of such a film leaves us finding "hard to believe" moments.  In ORPHAN, we're expected to believe that Sarsgaard is UTTERLY blind to what his new daughter is really like.  We're expected to accept that young Max (aged 5...beautifully played by newcomer Aryana Engineer...best name EVER!) is so thoroughly and completely under Esther's thrall that she would help commit some horrific crimes.  And the final few minutes of the film feature some very clichéd moments, including key characters deciding to run into a dark, snow covered forest for no good reason except to set up a climactic confrontation.

But again, to its credit, ORPHAN is adeptly handled to the degree where we don't think about a lot of these things until AFTER the movie.  It has built up enough goodwill (by creeping us out) that moments that might make us groan in disbelief in a lesser film will skate by here.

To its detriment, the film opens with a dream sequence...just to give us a jolt to start things off.  Jolts from dream sequences are not earned fairly, in my opinion...especially if you start a film with one.  And the sequence itself is a bit unpleasant to watch...there's nothing really nice about childbirth's gone bloodily wrong.

Vera Farmiga is an arresting film presence, and gives a decent performance here.  Sarsgaard, a real favorite of mine, is not quite so convincing here...I think it's the worst I've seen  him.  The oldest brother is played by young Jimmy Bennett (recently the young James T. Kirk in STAR TREK)...and he is quite good.  He's a typical obnoxious 12 year old boy...but when its up to him to help members of his family, he steps up even when he's utterly terrified.  But the film belongs (as it must) to young Fuhrmann...and even if the content & structure of the film fades into the memory with great speed...Esther will stick with you just a little bit longer.

3.5 stars for this solid, scary genre piece.  Rounded down to 3 due to the sordid opening sequence and uninspired final sequence.

I LOVED it! It's such a skillfully done thriller and one of the best in the evil kid sub-genre period. I loved the set-up. It doesn't take long and you find yourself really caring about this family. There's a wonderful scene early on when Farmiga's character is tucking her daughter into bed.

Not only is this entirely successful as a creepy suspense film and even a drama, but it's also downright hilarious. And yes, it's intentional. I loved its sense of humor. The things Esther would say and the way she would say them had me cracking up. She's delightfully evil. Even the murder scenes had me laughing. Just seeing this little girl being so cold and vicious provided a great thrill. And not in a sick way. It was just funny.

The performances are great. I found both Vera Farmiga and newcomer Isabelle Fuhrman as Esther to be fantastic.

I'd heard so much about the twist before seeing this movie without actually finding out what it was. Despite everyone saying how laughable it was I didn't want to find out until I saw the movie myself. I'm really glad I didn't. I don't think it would have been as enjoyable had I known the whole time. I never saw it coming either. That could be because it's so out there that it's nearly impossible to see it coming. Yet at the same time it wasn't nearly as outrageous as I was fearing judging by the way it was talked about. Thankfully I didn't find it hard to swallow and was able to go along with it. Is it realistic? Not exactly, but it worked fine. It only helps that everything before it was so great. The whole time I was scared that this supposedly horrible twist was going to ruin the movie for me. I'm so glad that wasn't the case.

This is a really wicked good time. At a hair over 2 hours it never felt too long. I was having too much fun with this gleefully twisted thrill-ride.

The snowy setting was a nice bonus.

It's been a while since we've had a movie where a child played the bad guy, or in this case, the bad girl. This movie really exceeded my expectations as I was expecting another predictable and corny horror flick. "Orphan" is billed as a horror movie, but in actuality it is a psychological thriller. Any way you slice it (no pun intended), this turned out to be a very good movie.

The first thing that comes to mind while watching this movie is "The Good Son" (1993), but "Orphan" has a better plot, more twists & turns, a more deranged child, and more surprises than you'd expect. Actually, Esther (the Orphan) is so evil and mentally disturbed that she makes "The Good Son" seem like a choir boy. Like other movies with this theme, the mother becomes suspicious early-on that something isn't quite right about the child, while the father plays the head-in-the-sand do-do who just doesn't get it until it's too late.

This flick is not about the supernatural or demons and such; it's just about one conniving, creepy, crazy a** kid who was adopted from an orphanage and who terrorized the hell out of a somewhat ordinary family struggling to overcome some tragic life events. This is one of those movies that you can't say too much about without giving away the entire plot, but I can say that "Orphan" is quite entertaining and is definitely worth seeing. It has great acting, a good plot, a great lead character, a little humor, numerous twists & turns, good suspense and a surprise ending. In fact, I'm anticipating a possible "Orphan II".

Move over Samara, Wednesday Addams and all you juvenile miscreants.  There's a new pint-size queen of evil and her name is Esther.  Brilliant, charming and oh-so-talented, she harbors a host of dark secrets behind her
innocent, smiling face.  But when you finally learn what they are it'll probably be too late.

Anyone who has read my prior movie reviews knows that I love good horror
and suspense films.  Unfortunately, nowadays most offerings in the genre are long on gore and short on story and character development.  That's not so with this time around, though.  Heavy on atmosphere and with very little blood, the movie relies more on suggestion, dark sets and outstanding acting to create its air of malevolence and all pervading evil.

The story concerns a tightly knit, loving family that is nonetheless marred by tragic events in its past, including the father's adultery and the mother's tumultuous recovery from alcoholism.  But the most heart wrenching nightmare they have endured is the loss of their third child, who was stillborn.  It weighs especially heavy on the mother, who struggles daily to cope with her depression and crushing sense of loss.

Seeking to make some good come of the horrific event, they adopt a highly intelligent, articulate and artistically gifted young girl from eastern Europe.  Her name is Esther, and at first she brings happiness and healing into their lives.  But soon they find out that she is not what she seems, no, not at all.

In my opinion the film's strongest asset is the brilliant performance by 12 year old actress Isabelle Fuhrman, who plays the title character.  She portrays Esther as a complex, multi-leveled character who possesses both admirable qualities and pathologically wicked desires.

During the movie my feelings for her went from affection, to pity, then to uneasiness and horror as her deepest, most twisted secret was revealed in a climactic moment that had me on the edge of my seat.

Set in Connecticut during a bleak winter, the icy scenery is the perfect backdrop for the tension that mounts throughout the movie.  Esther first takes revenge on a girl at school who mocks her for her unusual clothing and quiet, studious demeanor.  Then she turns on those who threaten to reveal her past.  Finally the family that has taken her into their home feels her wrath.  The mother alone suspects the truth, but finds herself outwitted by her psychopathic opponent at every turn.

The final 20 minutes or so were filled with twists that kept me befuddled as to how it would all end, and I am very good at figuring out hidden plot elements.  For example, I suffered the misfortune of figuring out the secret to "The Sixth Sense" very early in that film.

That was not the case this time.  The producers clearly took great pains to avoid the worn out devices used in one cheesy horror movie after another.  In their place they devised a story line so uniquely insidious that it hit me like a wall of bricks when it was finally revealed.

Haunting, disturbing, terrifying and unforgettable - all these words and more describe this outstanding film.  I strongly recommend you shell out the money for the tickets and popcorn and see this one on the big screen.  It's worth every penny.

I didn't want to see the Orphan until I read a spoiler review that gave away the ending. I would normally never read such a thing, but I had no intention of seeing this flick until it hit DVD. The concept behind the twist intrigued me enough to shell out some money and see this movie at matinee price. I wish I hadn't known the secret while watching the film, but I still was entertained thanks to some fine acting from both leads and a great performance from the little girl who played the evil Esther. Isabelle Fuhrman was only 11 or so at the time this was filmed, but as far as child actors go, she was the best I've seen in a very long time.

I have a couple of gripes. I hated all the times the music built up and the camera zoomed in behind a character only to find there was nothing there in the first place. I know it's a horror movie, but they managed to avoid most other cliches, so why keep throwing this one around? The film is also about 15 minutes too long and I thought the last 1/4 or so dragged a little bit.

The weird and unique twist ending, along with the acting, elevated the Orphan from 2 and 1/2 to a 4 star rating from me. The movie reminded me of The Good Son with Macualay Culkin at times, but this one has a much more serious mean streak, most of which involving young kids. This is rated R for a reason. It's way more brutal than I thought it was going to be, especially in the murder scenes commited by the child.

Overall, Orphan was worth the five bucks I paid to see it and it definitely should be a rental for any horror or suspense fan in the near future.

"There's something wrong with Esther," say the ads for "Orphan," and indeed, there is. I could just end the review with that, as it does pretty much tell you everything you need to know about the main character, an adopted girl who promises heaven and delivers hell. But then I'd miss out on the opportunity to tell you about all the other great things it has to offer. This is a truly great horror movie, ambitious enough to be frightening and absorbing, confident enough to toy with the conventions we know all too well, mature enough to rely on the talents of actors instead of the sex appeal of teenagers. Its greatest achievement is transcending the clich that is the precocious yet evil child, and while I'd like to elaborate on that, I'm afraid the nature of the plot doesn't allow for such details. Regardless, what happens is most likely not what you think will happen, which is to say that you'll actually be surprised.

Esther is played by Isabelle Furhman, a twelve-year-old playing a nine-year-old, although age doesn't count much here. She speaks with a flawless Russian accent and masterfully runs the emotional gamut between sweet and sadistic. Esther is a consummate manipulator, able to advertise herself as the nicest girl you'd ever want to raise as your own before switching gears and making those who stand in her way suffer. We first see her sitting all alone in the classroom of an orphanage, painting a colorful and happy picture that tells a story. Her dress is nice, if a little old fashioned, and the ribbons she has tied around her neck and wrists make her look like a princess. When she smiles, it's not the toothy perfection of a mouthwash commercial but a real girl's smile--so cute and innocent and loveable. Her words are eloquent, and she definitely possesses a wisdom beyond her years. Maybe the trauma of losing her parents back in Russia has forced her to grow up a little too fast.

For these very reasons, she immediately attracts the attention of a couple looking to adopt after a miscarriage claims the life of their third baby. Here enters Kate and John Coleman (Vera Farmiga and Peter Sarsgaard), who both carry a lot of baggage. Kate, once a successful piano teacher, is a recovering alcoholic who feels nothing but guilt. John, an architect, is a nice enough guy but takes everything at face value, a character flaw that ultimately proves disastrous.

Esther is adopted. Now things start to get tense. At school, she's made fun of for her clothing and her old, dilapidated Bible, and she screams bloody murder when someone goes to touch the ribbon on her neck. At home, she's hated by the Coleman's son, Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), who rightfully feels ignored by his parents. She soon forms an unhealthy bond with the Coleman's deaf young daughter, Max (Aryana Engineer), who eventually sees things that no little girl should ever have to see. As for the relationship between Esther and Kate, it gets progressively worse while the relationship with John gets progressively better. But Kate knows that there's something wrong with Esther, and it has nothing to do with the little things like dropping an F-bomb; it has to do with serious things, like Esther being present when her mean schoolmate falls from the top of a playground set and breaks her ankle.

One of the nuns from the orphanage, Sister Abigail (CCH Pounder), seems to think Kate is on to something: "Trouble has a way of finding her," she says of Esther, believing that a mistake might have been made in the adoption process. But what if they were nothing more than accidents? What if Kate is wrong? Is it possible that she's venting her resentments on a girl who has been through a lot? Is it possible that she should be back in rehab? Kate's therapist, Dr. Browning (Margo Martindale), seems to think so, and apparently, so does John. But what about their children? Let's just say they know more than care to admit. Think of it in terms of one of Esther's paintings; when you look it in a different light, you'll find that a completely different story is being told.

"Can you keep a secret?" the ads ask us ominously, if not altogether unexpectedly. Indeed, you should keep the film's big revelation to yourself, even if you found it unconvincing. Suspension of disbelief is required of you, yes, but fortunately, this is one of the few recent horror films that earns it. Why? Because the story doesn't resort to cheap gimmicks--it's a thriller that actually thrills. There are moments that seem to be leading up to a tired horror clich, only to throw us off guard with ... nothing. When a door or a medicine cabinet is opened, blocking the camera's view, what do you expect to see in the shot when the door closes? In this movie, you're never sure whether or not someone will suddenly appear out of nowhere. If it does happen, chances are it's for reasons other than a quick scare.

The more lasting scares involve Esther, who at one point or another makes use of a hammer, a gun, a vice, a knife, a pillow, a retractable blade, and a match with a bottle of lighter fluid. Even a car rolling backwards down a hill in neutral finds its way into the story. As has been repeatedly said, there's something wrong with Esther, a girl who makes little Rhoda from "The Bad Seed" seem like an amateur. "Orphan" is a first class shocker that begins with a nervous whisper before building to a cry and ending with a scream. Director Jaume Collet-Serra and writers Alex Mace and David Leslie Johnson actually made an effort; yes, their film is scary, and yes, their film is disturbing, but more to the point, their film is engaging.

"Orphan" is without a doubt one of the most silly and over-the-top suspense movies that I have seen in ages. It has everything. A couple (Peter Sarsgaard & Vera Farmiga) who are getting over a recent tragedy, a busy-body nun (CCH Pounder) who simply won't keep her nose out of other people's affairs, a deaf child (Aryana Engineer) who can probably communicate better than most people and then there's Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman). There are some scenes where you may even route for Esther because at first she comes off as the ultimate victim and who doesn't like a victim? Esther gets her revenge, but good. I thought it was hysterical how Kate got all up in arms when Esther nonchalantly said the F-curse. Umm, lady you were busy doing it in the middle of your kitchen, yet you get all disturbed because your newly adopted child who walks in on you says a naughty word. But, lemme just say if Esther  were my adopted child I would send her to the Leona Helmsley school for bad girls and she'd learn really quickly how to behave. Esther is actually hiding a dark and very shocking secret which will amaze you and cause you to gasp in horror (trust me, it's a biggie). But this movie is so much more than a suspense or a thriller. It's the ultimate game of cat and mouse. The question is, who is the cat and who is the mouse? Remember, don't repeat the surprise shock ending...

There's good reason why family plays well into horror movies--Amityville, The Shining, even Mama. Yes, there is good pathos to watching familial bonds be strained and broken by forces inside and out, but literature has always found rich material in family drama because families are complicated and, of course scary. When a couple lose their third child to a miscarriage, they decide to adopt a child instead <cue ominous music>. Of course their choice, Esther, proves to be the horror catalyst of the movie, but the subtext of her horror, at least at first, plays into the dual culture found within families, where parents and kids live in the same house but exist in different realities, and Esther knows how to play both sides. The ending unfortunately falls into Hand That Rocks the Cradle/Fatal Attraction area, with an unforgivable Seven-ripoff title sequence, which deflates pretty much everything the movie had built up, probably as some studio suit crunched the numbers on what would sell DVDs. But I do wonder when Vera Farmiga gets her props for bringing such talent to horror movie acting. She might not offer the kind of genre archetype Sigourney Weaver constructed, but she's definitely raised the bar on the kinds of performances we can expect.

What can I say about  Orphan? I went into this expecting very little since Ive seen this done so many times before, at times, with preposterous results (anyone remember the film Mikey?). This one manages to work and surpass expectations. It lays on the suspense, the nail-biting scenes that only the best of the genre are capable of providing. Kudos to the cast for the great performances, although Peter Sarsgaard may come across as a bit stiff (it doesnt help that his character is a bit of a jerk- don't blame the actor) his co-stars steal the spotlight with the stand-out being Isabelle Fuhrman, who plays that conniving little tyrant, that orphan gracing the DVD-Bluray cover who is surprisingly named Esther  such a benign name, Satan would be far more fitting.

The Colemans are a young, couple- the boring, arrogant John (Sarsgaard) and his recovering alcoholic wife, Kate (Vera Farmiga) who recently suffered a miscarriage. They adopt a charming little Russian girl, Esther (Fuhrnman) who appears mature for her age, speaks with a delightful accent (so cute) and can play a mean Tchaikovsky on the Colemens grand piano. She is received with welcoming arms by the couple's hearing impaired daughter, the adorable Maxine Max (Aryana Engineer) and with some hesitation from her brother Daniel (Jimmy Bennett).  Esther tries to fit in at home and school but she becomes the brunt of some cruel jokes and suspicions that begin to fuel her pent-up anger. Kate is the first to notice that there is something seriously wrong with Esther (understatement of the year). Trouble seems to follow her around, but Kates suspicions are met with skepticism and denial from her disbelieving husband. As Esthers malicious ways escalates, it becomes clear that no one is safe. Esther is conniving, she is cruel, she is evil and shes not what she appears to be. Mwahahahahahaha!!!

Directed by Jaume Collet-Serra, Orphan is a solid, well-made, well-acted thriller that is in my opinion, grossly under-rated. Despite a been-there-done-that scenario, Orphan fits right in alongside other child monster movies and manages to stand out as one of the better efforts. It works rather well, introducing us to the many characters; some we end up caring for, others- not so much; even the nasty little monster provides us with moments of sweet sentimentality and this is just confirmation of a competently told story. The film is also funny in a good horror movie kind of way (intentionally and unintentionally) and has many surprises up its sleeve. Although the film is violent, it is not gory and director Collet-Serra piles on the suspense by placing so many of the main characters in mortal danger while the main antagonist is so conniving, so bold in her quest for vengeance, she becomes all the more frightening as the film progresses. The situations we are presented with here are not that unbelievable where our suspension of disbelief has to work in over-drive (this is where the film Mikey lost it) and the final twist  yes, there is a twist, makes the situations even more plausible. The actors do their jobs well and all characters are believably played out. Although John Coleman is rather obnoxious and not very likable, he is played just right by Sarsgaard. Farmiga fares better as her character is more fleshed out and far more sympathetic- the recovering alcoholic who also falls prey to the sinister plans of Esther, and if there is one person in this film you are rooting for, it is Kate. However Isabelle Fuhrman steals the show. Her performance is so convincing, so bone-chillingly real, I am surprised she has not done more horror films. Her face oozes innocence and sheer wickedness  a deadly combination that is a treat to watch in a horror film. You can tell a great actor just by their facial expressions. The best ones do not even have to say one word to get their point and their intent across. Fuhrmans many scenes, where we see her character's sinister soul emanating through her eyes and smile, is played to perfection. She is sweet, oh-so-charming in one instant and a rabid, blood-thirsty pit-bull the next.

The film is not perfect. Many scenes were shot too dark to see any of the action clearly and despite its disturbing subject matter, it may not be as scary as one would expect. However, the film remains absorbing and as it moves a long, it grabs hold of your attention, never letting go until the final show-down. Definitely not what I expected. Admittedly, it was better and despite her nasty habit of killing people, this little orphan is worthy of your time especially if you're in the mood for a good, dark, twisted little horror movie.

this is really vera farmiga's film. she carries it every step of the way with her expressive and believable acting. by comparison her husband, therapist and the orphanage counselor occupy less nuanced roles. that clears the decks for a full exploration of the tension between this loving and damaged mother and her new adopted daughter. her *strange* adopted daughter.

what's up with that child? you can't put your finger on it. yes, you soon get the evidence that the family is in serious trouble. the script brings in the usual thriller subplots that require the child's schoolyard tormenter to get what she doesn't deserve, or the mother to dig into the child's obscure past, or the bland and clueless father to get his shocking realization. but none of this is to the question: what is the child's motivation, why does she do what she does?

well, there are clues along the way that don't quite fit in but that, at the end, make perfect sense. such as: why is this child afraid to go to the dentist? and why can she play the piano like a virtuoso?

there are some witty turns here and there -- this is perhaps the first film to cast a playground as a haunted house -- but there are some resonant touches of psychology as well -- the tensions in an adulterous marriage, the mother's grief and guilt, the sibling rivalries, the secrets. but what's up with that child? the final disclosure makes her plausible in an unexpected way, and the final battle between mother and daughter is kept roaring with one twist after another. a distinctive and engrossing thriller.

Isabelle Fuhrman, a 13 year old american actress has recieved critical acclaim for her performance in this film as Esther, an Orphan child born in Russia who now lives in an orphanage in the United states. Vera Farmiga(The Departed)and Peter Sarsgaard(Flight plan) play a couple looking to adopt a child. They meet Esther and find her compelling, bright, intelligent, and well mannered, so they decide to adopt her and she lives with them and their 2 other children. Their youngest daughter is nearly completely deaf and the family engages conversation with her via sign language. Esther at first appeals to every member of the family accept their son who finds her very odd, and he is embarrased by her strange personality and style of dress around his school pals, so he begins to resent her. But Esther easily connects with the rest of the family, especially their deaf youngest child. But Soon horrifying secrets are revieled as strange and sometimes deadly events take place. Esther shows how evil and twisted she really is. Both Farmiga and Sarsgaard make the perfect parents with strong performances, but most of what makes this film truly memorable and effective is the superb performance by Isabelle Fuhrman, who brings Esther to terrifying life. If this young actress can make a few right choices and be lucky enough to get a few more juicy roles over the next few years, she might very well become a superstar. I was very impressed by her performance. Pretty incredible work from an actress who was all of 12 years old when this film was shot. I eagerly look forward to seeing her again in other films in the future.

A family of four is torn apart after adopting a seemingly sweet and intelligent Russian girl. Her mysterious past catches up with them as a series of accidents befall the family members and anyone else that crosses Esther's path. ORPHAN was a big hit upon its release in 2009, despite its many setbacks that keep it from becoming a classic in the killer kids genre. The character of Esther is written and played far too menacingly for her to remain unnoticed. There is no ambiguity in her actions, as she is clearly portrayed as being evil from the very start. As a result, much of the film relies on the shock of her actions rather than the build up or suspense leading up to them. It does, however, manage to maintain the mystery behind her shady background long enough to give the audience one final surprise! Esther's adopted parents are easily the most frustrating parents in recent Horror. Her crackpot mother is irritating and irresponsible, while her idiot father stands completely oblivious to her evil ways in light of the horrible tragedies that are affecting his family. They gain no sympathy or support as a result. If films were graded solely on their twist endings, ORPHAN would rate at the top of its class, but the carelessness of the writing cannot be overcome by the clean cinematography or Isabelle Fuhrman's creepy performance as Esther.

-Carl Manes

After the death of a young child, a couple has been debating for a while whether to adopt another child to be a part of their family, they visit an orphanage and the wife Kate (Vera Farminga, "The Departed") sees a young girl named Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman, "Hounddog"). Kate and her husband John (Peter Sarsgaard, "Green Lantern") learn that Esther is from Russia, her last adopted family was killed in a house fire and she barely survived. Initially Esther while timid blends in well with the family even taking to playing with Kate and Peter's daughter Max (Aryana Engineer, in her debut role) who is deaf but quite smart. Their son however seems to think Esther is weird, which does come into play later in the film.

What follows is a slow reveal of Esther being perhaps just a little more than a normal little girl, as she pushes a girl off a slide who made fun of her at school, then she kills an badly injured bird right in front of the son and Max. This does sound like a pretty basic story of a disturbed orphaned kid, but the story by Alex Mace, David Leslie Johnson's screenplay and Jaume Collet-Serra's directing do lend some very good dark tones to this and they keep the chills and terror coming, even if the viewer can figure out whats gonna happen long before it does.

"Orphan" is actually a very well done movie, it has a feeling of dread everytime Esther is on screen as you're just waiting for something to happen, there's also the underlying storyline of troubles between Kate and John from things that happened in their recent past. The daughter's deafness does come into play during key parts of the movie and while most everyone does well in their roles Isabelle really breaks out as Esther as its easily one of the most layered characters from the thriller/horror genre in recent memory.

I was honestly floored when I saw critics call this film "unrealistic" due to the fact that everyone seems to trust Esther (the psychopath homicidal girl) over her truth-telling but seemingly paranoid mother and a typical "It's always the parents' fault, not the child's" incompetent but far-from-uncommon therapist. Most horror films suffer from intense unbelievability, but this is definitely not one of them. It's only because *we* see the truth do we wonder how everyone can believe Esther over her mother. What no one seems to grasp is that they *WANT* to believe what they say, and the motivations every character has are definitely not unreasonable--if they took the mother's word, they'd be jumping into blaming the child for such horrific things, and it would almost invariably end in a downward spiral that would tear an already-salvaged family apart.

I was impressed with the realism of every character. They even use the pathology "antisocial personality disorder" properly, and a totally believable family therapist who, like many other incompetent therapists, immediately blames the parents, not the children, for their problems. A therapist blaming the mother for her child's behavior is par for the course for many of these therapists, despite any and all evidence that the child is simply unruly, even with events that happen because of Esther.

The two biological family members, Max and Daniel, have been criticized for being unrealistic, for not talking after seeing Esther do such horrific things. This is a mistake by critics. These are young children we're talking about who are, naturally, terrified of Esther, who threatens them with such intimidation that they don't care about anything except keeping her away from them, which means keeping quiet under any and all circumstances. Such young children can't understand that type of situation and the seriousness of it, and I really don't think it's such a stretch to say they would do the simplest thing and avoid Esther entirely so they don't get hurt, rather than tell someone and risk Esther doing the terrifying things she says she'll do if they talk. If she said the same things to adults, their thinking would be more adult-like, but they're very small children not even in puberty.

Esther is also not an unbelievable character, and everyone's unwillingness to blame her despite that she *probably* had something to do with all of the happenings around her is perfectly natural. And the reason for that is because there's really no *actual* evidence that she was involved, and it would be unfair to blame an otherwise well-behaved child, and an orphan with a troubled past, at that. No one would be comfortable going against the quick consensus that the mother is just transferring her own guilt onto Esther. Not even her husband would be able to get past that in the real world. In terms of credibility, Esther simply wins by a landside. The mother is a recovering alcoholic and has periods of mental instability. Esther is a well-behaved, intelligent, and creative orphan who simply knows how to manipulate others behind their backs. She knows that they'll blame the mother the more she complains about Esther for things she can't find real evidence for. Esther is smart. The mother has no chance of winning the credibility war with no real evidence against Esther.

Anyway, people who are complaining about how there's no way Esther could do the things she does and also that other kids would cover for her out of fear are mistaken. None of that is unrealistic given the context. The mother already starts off as someone to be watched for instability, and already lacks credibility before they even take Esther in. When her mother insists Esther is responsible for the bizarre happenings going on, we're talking about a not-so-perfect unstable mother against a well-behaved, creative child who knows exactly how to cover her own tracks, and in fact likes that her mother is so enraged about it, which only helps her own stability come off as credible.

This is really an excellent thriller, one of my favorites. Esther is a true psychopath to the letter, and the way the film treats the nature of psychopathy is exceptional. It's a believable story, and the two hours rocket by while we watch Esther's psychopathy manifest more and more, and the suspense never lets up. Extremely highly recommended for horror and thriller fans.

After all, doesn't it say "There's something wrong with Esther" right on the cover of the movie?! What we don't know is WHY Esther is this way. And actually, that never really becomes clear. You would think if Esther could finally just find a family to stick with, maybe she could have somewhat of a normal life. After all, this family cared about her, and if people hadn't been dropping like flies, no one would have investigated. Anyway, we find out that Esther is really a grown woman with dwarfism. I just rewatched this last night, and I must say that I am so surprised that I ever liked it. Ok, sure, it is well acted, well lit, and well shot, but the story is so preposterous it isn't even funny. Plus, it's edited very poorly, and has an entirely wrong feel for the story that is being told here.

Yes, everything good about it, like the good lighting, color schemes, acting, etc etc, all work against the mere simplistic evil child storyline here. And nothing is ever really established as to any of the main character's motives. Yes, it shows that the mother suffered a miscarriage (in the over the top gory opening scene), but that doesn't really explain to me why they would want to adopt a child (who is almost fully grown, mind you), when they already have children. ?

I could understand if they were childless, but they already have two children. Plus, if they really wanted another child, why not adopt a newborn baby? ? Anyways, enough about that lapse in logic.

And, as for things not ever been really clearly established, well, that also goes for a lot of other scenes in the film. Namely, it is never explained (or fully explored) why the children react the way they do around Esther at school. Plus, the early scenes of little orphan Esther at school had me rooting for her, because it was the other children that came across as the bad seeds, and she was just some innocent outsider. And the whole scene in the playground, I found myself way too distracted wondering why the little girl was so afraid of the orphan girl, that it robbed the film of any form of suspense that it was trying to build in the moment.

And the entire "bad seed" plot is kind of well forgotten by the third act, because the tone of the entire picture has shifted so dramatically that it in no way no longer really resembles what it was when it started. Plus, this was such a confused story. I don't mean confusing, but confused, in that it didn't really know what it wanted to be: Was it a thriller, or a horror movie, or was it an erotic thriller that happened to have the "good child is really evil" subplot? (Oh, yes, did I mention that this had way too many over-the-top erotic scenes in it that served absolutely no purpose what-so-ever.)

And the entire thing was so way way way over the top it isn't even funny. Ok, well, maybe it is, but not in the way the filmmaker would want it to be. I found myself laughing at the movie so many times I lost count. And I was laughing at them, not with them!

Everything is handled in such a heavy handed way, it robs the film of any genuine thrills it should have. There were some scenes that were shot so well, and so well lit, I could watch them over and over, if they were in another film. This may have been better serviced if maybe shot on a lower budget. ? But, as it is, there are way too many well crafted shots wasted on this kind of story.

And don't even get me started on the father in this. He is possibly the most irritatingly stupidest character in all horror film history. And especially when he actually broke down and cried in front of the orphan girl, LMAO, how pathetic was that! I wanted to kill him myself!

And that leads me to yet another problem I have with this movie (matter of fact, I had this problem the first time I saw it): The extremely over-the-top, gory, gruesome murder of his character. The way it was filmed made me feel like I was inside a snuff film, because it was just too gritty, and again, completely out of tone with the rest of the film.

Plus, I almost felt like by that time in the movie, no more characters really needed to be killed off. It was such a blatantly bad decision in plotting in my opinion. And, then, this leads me to the extremely bad, over the top (notice a theme here, lol) ending. Wow, could "Halloween's" ending be ripped off anymore??? You know, the thing that would not die, no matter what you do to it, you know, like, stab it, set it on fire, stab it some more, shoot it, drown it, stab it some more, and IT STILL KEEPS COMING BACK FOR MORE!

This is definitely a "shut your brain off at the start" kind of movie, and even kind of good for a first time viewing, if all you're out for is some kind of cheap, dumbed down quick thrill, but if you're like me, and like your movies to be a little bit more cerebral and challenging, then you may wanna skip this one. I sure wish I did! Thank you. :>)

Simply put, Isabelle Fuhrman dominates the screen as Esther, a cute 9-year-old Russian girl adopted by a loving family that wishes to fill the void of a recent pregnancy that resulted in a stillborn.  Adopted by John and Kate (Peter Sarsgaard and Vera Farmiga, respectively), Esther soon ratchets up the mystery and tension in this suspense thriller.  At odds are the family's two children; innocent Max (Aryana Engineer), who forms a quick bond with Esther, and surly Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), who irritated me and Esther from the very moment the camera began rolling.

Esther appears to be a great addition to the family, what with her old-fashioned appearance, ribbons and dress like a Little Bo Peep story, but soon enough Kate becomes more curious and suspicious of the talented little girl's background.  Meanwhile, John plays the role of doormat, making bad decisions and letting his somewhat abrasive wife dominate screen time.  Rather than pimping their children out for reality show riches, this John and Kate bicker weakly about their new daughter and the effect she is having on their family.

What unfolds is an exercise in tension and patience.  While Kate slowly unravels the mystery, Esther shows wisdom by manipulating everyone towards her side.  Those against her?  Not so lucky.

The most compelling part of Orphan, and what saved the film's slow pace, was the performance of Fuhrman.  At 11-years old she possesses the acting chops to pull off a flawless Russian accent while displaying emotional range of which most adults are incapable.  With a flick of the emotional switch, she changes from innocent to sadistic, friendly to evil.  A very convincing performance.

For once it seems Hollywood was capable of making a movie that didn't rely on the one-second shock scares.  Dark to light.  Quiet to loud.  This pleased me quite a bit while watching this movie.  Director Jaume Collet-Serra and screenplay writer David Johnson have created an ambitious film that doesn't fit into the mold of most current horror or suspense thrillers; what they have made is almost old-fashioned.  There is very little in the way of ambiguity; what's evil is evil, what's good is good.  It's up to the viewer to follow a path.  Regardless of choice, the ending is quite a surprise.

Ester is a dwarf in her 30's pretending to be a NINE year old girl...um...yeah...believable? NO! Why? Here are my reasons:

1) Even the kind of dwarfism where the person has a body proportioned like a full size human, they still have different facial proportions. An adult dwarf and a normal size child would not have the same facial structure. The reason dwarf actors don't play children's roles in movies is because YOU CAN TELL THE DIFFERENCE VERY EASILY! This is why the character had to be played by a child actor because it would have been impossible for a dwarf to look convincing in this role.

2) The skin of a dwarf would still just like a full size woman. She is supposed to be in HER 30'S? How many thirty something women have skin like a 9 year old girl? NOT POSSIBLE! Women have Botox and facelifts and still don't look like they are 18, let alone 9! Even a 9 year old and a 20 year old woman clearly have DIFFERENT skin! I have seen dwarfs up close and their skin ages like every other human. Wouldn't the mom notice that her "9 year old" has as many crow's feet as she does?

3) Fat deposits. People gain and lose fat as they age and as we know, this isn't always in the best or most flattering of places. A woman in her 30's would have body fat in places where women gain it as we age. Even if women are thin they will usually lose some fat in the face, gain some in the jawline etc.

4) Hair. Hair can thin and turn gray with age. Adult hair also has a different texture. So this 30 something woman has perfect skin like a 9 year old, a body that can pass as a kid AND no gray hair or hair loss?

5) Hands. Anyone with kids knows that the hands of a child are very smooth...like it or not there is no hand treatment in the world that will make your hands look like your 9 year old kid! If there was, it would make millions! Even models and celebrities who spend tons of money on their looks still have hands that for the most part, match their age range.

6) Voice. An adult, even a dwarf would probably not be able to sound like a 9 year old. Just like a dwarf and a child don't look alike, they usually don't sound alike either.

Apart from the plot twist not being realistic the movie isn't really scary...unless you are afraid of insane and inhumanly strong knife wielding dwarfs wearing silly schoolgirl outfits! It fails at delivering the scare but it delivers the creepy. Once scene in particular where Ester puts on a much-too-grown-up looking black dress and tries to seduce an adult man, is just GROSS and CREEPY and not in a good way! The movie tried hard to be original and it tried hard to be scary and it failed on both attempts. It had blood, gore and violence but it wasn't scary enough to be a horror flick and it wasn't thrilling enough to be a thriller. After a while, blood and gore isn't really scary especially if it doesn't have a plot to carry it.

This movie made me wish for the good old days...when creepy children and scary music meant that they were possessed by Satan, cursed by some witch, in an evil mind control cult, or turned into zombies...or something that made sense! A knife wielding 30 something dwarf pretending to be a 9 year old so she can kill entire families for no good reason DOESN'T make sense! I give it two stars instead of one because of Isabelle Fuhrman. The other actors were forgettable (the parents were especially bad and wooden acting) but I thought she gave this role 100%. If she was a 25 year old masquerading as a 13 year old girl that MIGHT have been a little more realistic. 9 and 30 is just too much of a stretch. If it's a thriller, it needs better suspense, better plot and less gore...If it's a horror movie it should have crazier gore and a more sinister, scary plot twist with some really dark evil stuff thrown in for good measure. A 4'0 tall psychotic adult just isn't that scary. Also, gore is only scary if it's SHOCKING! It isn't shocking when it is overused, especially when the pace and the plot isn't there to back it up. If nothing else the disparate viewer reactions to "The Orphan" make for interesting reading on these comment pages. My advice for potential viewers is to disregard the most extreme love-hate stuff; the film is neither as good nor as bad as a lot of people are saying.

  It is basically a slightly more bent and graphic version of Julia Stiles' 1998 film "Wicked". Both films revolve around ruthless jockeying for household supremacy, both have an erotic subtext that people seem to be afraid to discuss, and both push the envelope of the "Bad Seed" (1956) genre-reflecting the more extreme attitudes of current fans of the psychological horror genre.

  "Orphan" had a much bigger budget than the earlier films which it quite skillfully utilized in useful areas like production design and cinematography. It is very creative in these areas and Esther (the latest "demon seed"- nicely overplayed by Isabelle Fuhrman) gets a nice dimensionality from the regular showcasing of her art. The painting of the burning orphanage is especially well done and extremely effective; being as creepy as any visual image I have ever seen.

  I would certainly recommend the film to fans of "Wicked" (and vice versa) and to even causal fans of the horror genre. I think it is too extreme for crossover fans, who would be wise to avoid the film or at least to be prepared to bail at some point because it gets increasingly twisted as it progresses. Unless you are willing to suspend disbelief during a number of plot developments you won't enjoy the viewing. It is a bit like "May" (2002) in this regard, where a lot of viewers enjoy the premise and the set-up but lose interest when the characters get too extreme or too stupid for audience identification.

  It is a long film (slightly over two hours), which would not be a problem if they had focused more on solving the mystery of Esther's background. Because the film offers viewers minimal cerebral exercises like this, their attention wonders to plot holes and the film begins to get a bit tedious.

  Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

Peter Sarsgaard portrays John, the husband, whom we soon learn has some fidelity issues, thus creating tension between the spouses. Isabelle Fuhrman, as Esther, steals the spotlight as the disturbed adopted daughter. When Kate begins to suspect something is very wrong with Esther, she can't get her husband to even give credence to her concerns. He brushes her off as if she's nothing. I began to despise him early on for his cluelessness and his inability to see what was staring him in the face. In the end, though, everyone is a believer. And not to give away the surprises, just be sure to watch closely as the layers of this secret begin to unfold. I probably would have given this one 4.5 stars, if I could. I deducted a star because, despite the compelling nature of this film, it isn't one I'll ever watch again.

When Kate (Farmiga) loses her third child during birth, it sends her marriage into a nose dive and drives her to therapy. Kate and John decide that the best way to do this is to adopt a child. They visit the local Orphanage and are almost instantly drawn to a young girl called Esther (Fuhrman). Esther is from Russia, she is polite and intelligent, and with an old fashioned dress sense and way about her that sets her apart from the other children. Three weeks after their visit to the Orphanage, Kate and John return to collect Esther and take her back home to become part of the family; and that's when things really take a turn for the worse, as they realise that Esther's sweet little eccentricity's are the least of their worries.

So Sondra and Seer sauntered (yes, I am alliterate) down to the local orphange to see if there were any good prospects. Sister Abagail greeted us and in the process I met Esther. She was sitting all alone by herself creating pictures. I was astounded that they were so good for such a young child. And people, I know good art. I did give Picasso lessons after all. Soon Sondra joined us and she was equally as impressed. Esther was remarkable. Creative, well-mannered, attentive, respectful, intelligent and, well, everything every child should be in this mad, a go-go crazy world we all know. At that point I should have been suspicious, however I wasn't (Seers do have lapses you know. One of the very few faults they have I might add). Unfortunately (or fortunately) we missed our chance. Sister Abigail called us the next day to tell us that a couple, Kate and John Coleman, decided they wanted her and papers were being drawn up at that very moment. Anyway, that brings us to the story of the Colemans. It seems Kate lost a child in pregnancy and needed a child to make her life complete. First off, she wore ridiculous dresses to school, the kids taunted her, and plus she had this Russian accent that took getting used to. Now, all young couples have their problems. Kate and John were no different, but they had moved beyond the issues of alcoholism and infidelity before Esther arrived. However, we learn that Esther is a master at manipulation and using people's psychological weaknesses to her advantage. So, she became a virtual wedge between the family and exploited their fears and insecurities against each other.
Not only that, but strange things were starting to happen. Unfortunate things. Her behaviour started to concern Kate a lot, but John felt that Kate was out on an imagination limb. Kate was in contact with Sister Abagail and when Sister Abigail came for a visit, Mother Superior not only jumped the gun, but jumped the icy curb as well.

More and more Kate suspected something wrong with Esther and did reserach over the internet to find out what. Esther, upon psychological investigation,was found to be totally normal and Kate was perceived as a paranoid nut case. So much for experts. Vera Farmiga, Peter Sarsgaard, and CCH Pounder give excellent performances, but it's the kiddies who steal the show in "Orphan."

Farmiga and Sarsgaard star as Kate and John Coleman, a successful and loving (or so it seems at first) couple with two children and the desire to adopt another when Kate's third child is stillborn.  They believe that they've found the perfect child in Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman), a nine-year-old Russian orphan who is sugary sweet, highly intelligent, and very artistic.

Once Esther arrives at the Coleman home, she is immediately met with resistance by the Coleman's son, Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), and takes their deaf daughter, Max (Aryana Engineer) under her protective wing.  She is also teased at school for her dresses and the Bible she carries with her.

Slowly the viewer sees sweet Esther turn into a very dark and sinister little girl.  Not only does she seek out revenge on those who pick at her, but she begins to manipulate Max and force her to help out with her dirty work.

Esther also opens old wounds from Kate and John's past and drives a wedge between them.  Kate becomes suspicious of Esther and seeks out more information on her newly adopted daughter.  The head mistress of the orphanage, Sister Abigail (CCH Pounder), tries to help Kate and becomes a target for Esther as well.

As Esther's dark past is revealed, her actions become more wicked and, in some cases, fatal.  It is at this point that the film begins to rely on well-worn cliches that have been trod out in a number of other films about evil children, particularly "The Good Son" and "The Omen."

Naturally there is a twist thrown in near the film's climax in order to give a motive to Esther's madness, and while it is rather sickening, it's not that big of a surprise.

Overall, the film isn't that bad.  However, clocking in at a very slow moving 120-plus minutes makes for a somewhat boring experience.  I'm assuming that director Jaume Collet-Serra was trying to build suspense by drawing out the film, but it makes for a lackluster thriller in the end.  Even the climactic battle near the end of the film is drawn out and rather unbelievable.  It's almost as if the film is attempting to be a psychological thriller and a slasher flick at the same time.

Again, the film really isn't that bad, just too long and a bit boring at times.  The children all shine in their roles, particularly little Aryana Engineer, whom I believe does an excellent job as Max.  Her performance is overshadowed somewhat by Fuhrman's turn as Esther, but she still shines on her own.

ORPHAN

STARRING: Vera Farmiga, Peter Sarsgaard, Isabelle Fuhrman, Jimmy Bennett, Aryana Engineer and CCH Pounder

WRITTEN BY: David Johnson and Alex Mace

DIRECTED BY: Jaume Collette-Serra

Rated: R
Genre: Horror / Thriller
Release Date: 24 July 2009

I'd be lying if I said that Orphan didn't have all the little moments you have seen a thousand times in horror flicks and thrillers. You know the ones I mean; the loud noises, the fast camera jerks and the annoying false-alarm-scares. It has them all. So why did I give it such a high rating you might ask?

Because although it has all of those little tidbits that feel like fillers and has a premise that's been recycled countless times, it has much more than any of the films you are thinking of. It makes movies like The Omen and Rosemary's Baby look like Disney films in comparison. Orphan is beyond disturbing.

We feel like a silent guest in the home of Kate (Vera Farmiga) and John (Peter Sarsgaard) Coleman. We feel their love for one another and the love for their children, Max and Daniel but we also sense dark secrets and an essence of mistrust as well. The family is holding it together but there have been some issues, for sure.

Kate is a recovering alcoholic and has miss-carried their third child in a very late stage of pregnancy. She had a name picked out and everything. She even dedicated a patch of rare flowers that she grows indoors to the unborn child.

This is obviously why things are a bit off with the family, so she and John agree to look into adopting. They've done a pretty decent job raising the two kids they already have, so it's no wonder they are fond of nine-year-old Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman) when they meet her at an orphanage. It's almost hard to believe she can be just nine. She is a very talented artist, plays the piano effortlessly and insists on dressing elegantly all the time. Despite all of this, she is without a doubt creepy.

As you may have guessed, at first everything is great. She gets along with the other kids, the parents love and adore her and all is well. Then things start happening. There is a close call here and a questioning concern there and then things get nasty.

What sets Orphan apart from similar films of its genre, is that things don't just get bad, they get really, really bad. This kid is one disturbed little individual.

Perhaps what made kids scary in movies in the past, was that they were just kids doing bad things. What makes Esther so terrifying is that she acts like an adult when she does them. She's too mature and smart for her own good and that's more horrifying.

At times it's almost like she is more aware of things than the parents. I think another factor that works is the way she dresses. They could have very easily tried to make her look eerie with dark clothes and Goth makeup and have her not say anything. Instead they chose to dress her up like a little church girl, complete with ribbons in her hair and dress shoes and they gave her a huge vocabulary and a grown up sense to know things that no child should know.

Another element it has that most horror films lack, is good acting. Every character is portrayed so well, it's insane.

Vera Farmiga makes us feel her pain in every scene. She is an extraordinary actress and is severely underrated. It was nice to finally see her in a lead role.

Peter Sarsgaard may very well be one of the best actors out there. I have seen several of his films and he has so much diversity between his characters. Here he plays denial that anything is wrong with Esther to a T and his chemistry with Farmiga is always believable.

Even the other two child actors who play Max, (Aryana Engineer) and Daniel (Jimmy Bennett) did amazing jobs. They both are so convincing that they're horribly scared, you can't help but wonder if they will need therapy after making this movie.

The director, (Jaume Collette-Serra) clearly has a knack for horror films, a previous film being 2005's House of Wax, which was also done very well. He keeps you on the edge of your seat and rips amazing performances out of all the actors.

The third act of the film was by far the most interesting. All bets are off for predicting anything that will happen. I was shocked repeatedly and amazed by the ending. This was easily the most original ending I have seen in any film since The Sixth Sense.

It's good to see that there can still be some decent horror films made. And it's reassuring as an avid horror fan, to know that good solid actors like Farmiga and Sarsgaard are interested in the material and that talented directors like Collette- Serra are behind the reins. Even mainstream icons like Michael Bay, Peter Jackson, Sam Raimi, and Martin Scorsese have been conjuring up new horror films.

It will probably take several years, if ever, for anyone to see Isabelle Fuhrman as not creepy. She does for scary little kids what Anthony Hopkins did for deranged serial killers. I wonder how this role has affected her because she conveys such evil in her performance, that you are impressed and repulsed simultaneously. And I also wonder if her parents will have any trouble finding a babysitter after this.

The poster and trailers make Orphan look like a horror movie, but it's not. I won't spoil the surprise except to say it's a suspense/thriller. As such it's a pretty good way to spend movie night if you don't expect too much or think too hard. Twist endings are de rigueur for the horror/suspense genre, with some directors thinking the more ludicrous and outlandish, the better. Thankfully, Orphan doesn't insult the audience's intelligence with a cheap surprise ending just for the sake of twist endings (see The Village). All the characters in here act naturally and do things that are logical for who they are, unlike some movies where the director shows characters doing things to intentionally mislead the audience or other red herrings, even when they are alone, like in Wild Things. The revelation at the end is credible and logical, though it shouldn't be a big shock unless you've totally switched off your brain before pushing the play button. The ending does not require a huge suspension of disbelief, and while you may not have guessed it, it won't leave you thinking you've been conned. I commend director Jaume Collet-Serra for taking us on a little side road along this well-traveled path (Child's Play,The Omen [Blu-ray], The Bad Seed). The film is mostly devoid of the usual cheap tricks that characterize horror/thriller films, like sudden loud music when a door opens, things popping out, or the slow, closely-framed behind the shoulder shot that suddenly cuts to a scary person behind the victim or a face in the mirror (accompanied by loud music). "There's something wrong with Esther", as the tagline says, and I didn't find any spots where I jumped in my seat. The Orphan does not produce an intense feeling of tension or fear, and instead, settles for a slow, hovering mood of creepiness before leading to the explosive final confrontation. Of note are Isabelle Fuhrman (Esther), 12, and Aryana Engineer, 8, who plays Max the hearing impaired and mute little sister (she is hearing impaired in real life). Fuhrman's fake Russian accent is distracting at times, but her acting abilities are apparent. Sure, her orphan character is a cliche, but Furhman's performance is perfectly creepy and cold. While not ground-breaking, the Orphan is a worthwhile flick to enjoy on a dark evening.

In this fine suspense/psychological horror film, an affluent couple in Connecticut decides to adopt a new child (she already has two children, one deaf, and has just lose her third in a miscarriage) and settles in an orphanage for a seemingly charming and very precocious nine year old Russian girl named Esther. Soon, though, the new member of the family shows a maturity well beyond her years and starts making terrible mischief with an escalating maliciousness that knows no boundaries, manipulating every member of the family to turn against each other and soon involving herself in real (as opposed to merely psychological) violence. Her adopted mother starts to suspect a terrible secret lies behind her. Eventually, things will escalate to murder. Well filmed (though there are too many false suspense moments) and especially well scripted, this movie has a final twist that I will not discuss here as not to spoil it to future viewers, but let me say that it is very nifty, it makes a lot of sense of what we just see before and puts this movie well above other run of the mill demon child stories. 12 year old's Isabelle Fuhmann performance as Esther is just mind blowing. Vera Farmiga, as the troubled mother seeing with impotence how this girl from hell is breaking her family is also fine.

I haven't seen her in anything else, but she seems more experienced that all of the child actors out there.

Many people find that describing the movie to give a movie review is the way to go. Usually, I refrain, but on this occasion, I will include the plot. The movie moves at a slow but determined pace for the first 45 minutes or so, but then the rockin' starts to rollin' as the story spirals into a cacophony of strangeness accompanied with mountains of vindictive mayhem. Many reviews I have read had a problem with the twist; I thought it to be VERY COOL, and something that could become reality in the realm of possibility, which makes it all the more founded, thus being all the more horrific. Just before the twist; however, something happened that made me think, "Okay, here we go...right back into the silly Hollywood horror film crap that has been bombarding us throughout the beginning of the new century." But when the twist hits and everything finally makes sense, I was thankfully pulled from that train of thought and taken back into a bizarre and wonderful story. Dark Castle Entertainment has done a LOT of movies that I simply love (Gothika, Ghost Ship, and Thirteen Ghosts.) This one will have to go into that group of five-star movies. Don't miss it!
FIVE STARS ***** for everything being done the way it should be done!

She is gifted with emotions and timing that reminded me of Kirsten Dunst in INTERVIEW WITH A VAMPIRE, and she's only twelve. You just can't take "Orphan" too seriously. From the lengthy (and "bloody") opening sequence to the jaw-dropping finale, the story of this "bad seed" horror film directed Jaume Collet-Serra (remake version of "House of Wax") remains preposterous. That doesn't mean "Orphan" is not worth watching, however. The film is fairly entertaining as long as you can ignore the obvious plot holes, graphic violence and, well, the "twist" that will leave most viewers speechless.

Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman) is a 9-year-old orphaned Russian girl. Sociable and charming, Esther is adopted by John Coleman (Peter Sarsgaard) and his wife Kate Coleman (Vera Farmiga) who has lost her baby recently. At first everything goes well and John and Kate are both very happy until one day Kate starts to feel that something is not quite right about Esther, a girl with a serene smile.

"Orphan" is largely well-acted (Isabelle Fuhrman as enigmatic Esther is quite impressive), but it takes too much time for the film to get things moving. Also, several episodes make the characters look very stupid - if someone claims that his child, severely wounded, is "pushed" by my child, I would take the matter much seriously than the Colemans.

But what is most disappointing is that Jaume Collet-Serra has missed so many chances to make the film a better thriller. There is a scene where Esther shows her sexual side, but that aspect of the storyline is not fully explored. John and Kate Coleman have two children, 12-year-old Daniel (Jimmy Bennett) and very adorable Max (Aryana Engineer), but their presence in the story as unprotected family member doesn't really enhance the suspense. Maybe I am wrong, but somehow the Spanish-born director Jaume Collet-Serra is forced to pull punches where he knows he shouldn't.

I saw this film when it opened on July 24, 2009. Mixed reviews from fans and critics were the usual flair upon its release, but something struck me about this movie. The film went on to gross $37 million at the box-office despite the thrashing it took from critics, but everyone couldn't help but notice the Oscar-nomination worthy performance of its 12-year-old star Isabelle Fuhrman. I just viewed the film on DVD for the first time since its theaterical run and I'm still seeing just how riveting and engaging this movie really is.

"Orphan" is NOT a horror film. It's more along the lines of a SUSPENSE THRILLER. When I think of horror films, I think of sex-crazed teenagers being sliced up one-by-one by a machete-wielding maniac (Jason Voorhies, Freddy Krueger, Micheal Myers, etc.). The only real weapons wielded here is just a hammer, a knife, and a .38-caliber pistol. You think scary when it comes to horror films and "Orphan" isn't scary. Has some frightful moments, yes, but scary? Wishful thinking!

Set in the winter-bound parts of Conneticut & Canada, the story centers on the Coleman family: Kate (Vera Farmiga), a Yale University music teacher recovering from alcoholism and bouts of depression after having a stillborn from her third pregnancy; John (Peter Sarsgaard), an architech whose nice guy persona overshadows his increasing issues with Kate that led to past affairs; Max (Aryana Engineer), their deaf 5-year-old daughter who communicates through sign language and their oldest son Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), who feels bitterly neglected & increasingly isolated from his parents. As a way of coping with the loss of their would-be 2nd daughter, Jessica, and to amend their existence as a family, Kate & John make a fateful decision to adopt a young girl at the local orphanage.

It is here where they meet Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman), a sweet-looking 9-year-old Russian girl harboring some deep-seeded issues of her own despite her angelic smile and sympathetic mannerisms. Upon arriving home with new stepdaughter in tow, a series of events unravel to make everyone question the background and sincerity of this little girl. Daniel dislikes her immediately, Max forms an unhealthy bond with her new stepsister, Kate begins to seek out further information about Esther's background, & John just plays Devil's Advocate with all that occurs involving Esther. What's wrong with Esther? Is it true that behind the smile of this little angel beats the heart of a psycho killer?

The answer, and the big secret about who she really is, lies within the confines of this 123-minute thriller. I agree with everyone here that it moves at a near-torturous snail's pace, that being the film's major fatal flaw. But the story itself is so entralling and engaging, you can't help but to excuse that misfire. Fuhrman's performance alone keeps you involved in the twists and turns entrenched here. Only a young, superbly talented actress like Fuhrman was able to pull off a psychological undertaking of switching from sympathetic manipulator to disturbed sadist and it's why I feel she should've gotten an Oscar nod. But due to the overall dislike of the film itself from most critics and for her young age, she didn't get anywhere near sniffing distance of the balloting.

Nonetheless, I was so inspired by this film and became such a fan that I created my own 20-song, hard-rock CD Mix (liner notes & all) of songs inspired by the movie (my own psuedo-soundtrack, if you will, but John Ottman's score was cool). Seemingly destined to go down as a cult favorite, if not a classic, "Orphan" was a solid & enjoyable thrill ride that's essentially "The Hand That Rocks The Cradle", "The Good Son", "The Crush", and a more mean-spirited version of "Problem Child" all rolled into one. That's why this movie isn't a horror despite being classified as one. This film has a depth, substance, and intuitiveness to it that Jason, Micheal, & Freddy couldn't touch with a bloddy axe. Just take sweet, little Esther home and let her hold you, thrill you, kiss you, .... kill you!!! Can someone out there please say "CULT CLASSIC"? - DEM -

This nifty old-school thriller pulled extremely mixed reviews when it landed in theaters last summer.  Because my two most trusted critics liked it (Ebert and Owen Gleiberman from EW), I went to see it and enjoyed it immensely.

Now that the film is on DVD (and now that I know the twist), I can appreciate the movie again from a fresh perspective, and I still think it's a first-class piece of suspense, as well as one of the best "evil child" movies I've ever seen.  (It also beats "Joshua" hands-down, despite what the critic Amazon cites above says.)

Really, the script is tight, the direction is fine, and most of all, the performances are excellent.  Except for the fact that thrillers rarely get their due at Oscar time, Farmiga and Fuhrman both give Oscar-worthy performances, and CCH Pounder makes a memorable impression as well.

But I must note two major caveats: the pace is slow and deliberate; folks with ADD will never make it all the way through the film, or they'll be fiddling with their Blackberries halfway through the first reel.  Those who like a well-crafted piece of suspense will settle in and enjoy the ride, however.

The second caveat: under NO circumstance should children under 10 see this film!!!  In fact, I have to assume that the producers had counselors on the movie set to explain "this is just a story" to the child actors; little Esther really terrorizes her adopted siblings, as well as one unfortunate classmate!

The only reason I have deducted one star is the lack of special features on the DVD.  There are some brief extra scenes plus an alternate ending (which is creepy but not as exciting as the regular ending), but that's it.  NO "making of" featurette, NO commentary.  In particular, I would have liked to have heard what Fuhrman and the other kids thought of the movie, whether they had nightmares, etc.

So Warner Brothers, like the critics, did this chilling thriller a significant disservice.  Judging from the majority of favorable reviews here at Amazon, I have to believe that this film's reputation will improve over the years, and perhaps after a decade or two, WB will release a "Special Edition" with the extra features such a fine effort deserves.

The movie is a little worried that its audience won't be able to sustain their attention, so there are a few absolutely pointless jump scares up front. Does ANYONE enjoy these?
